content.description: Tobacco use disorder involves a problematic pattern of tobacco (e.g., cigarettes, cigars, smokeless tobacco, vaping nicotine) use leading to clinically significant impairment or distress. Withdrawal occurs upon cessation or reduction in use after prolonged daily intake.

mechanisms: Nicotine binds to nicotinic acetylcholine receptors, releasing dopamine in the mesolimbic pathway.
Chronic exposure leads to neuroadaptations and dependence.
Withdrawal symptoms result from reduced dopamine and other neurotransmitter dysregulation.

diagnostic_criteria.use_disorder: Problematic pattern of tobacco use with ≥2 DSM-5 criteria within a 12-month period (e.g., craving, unsuccessful quit attempts, continued use despite harm).
diagnostic_criteria.withdrawal: Daily or near-daily use for several weeks followed by cessation/reduction, with ≥4 symptoms within 24 hours: irritability/anger, anxiety, difficulty concentrating, increased appetite, restlessness, depressed mood, insomnia.

content.prevalence: About 14% of U.S. adults smoke cigarettes; higher rates among those with psychiatric disorders.
content.prognosis: High relapse rates without treatment; multiple quit attempts often required for sustained abstinence.

history: Type of tobacco/nicotine product, amount, and frequency.
History of quit attempts, duration of abstinence.
medical_workup: Screen for oral lesions and cancers.

use_disorder: Difficulty cutting down despite desire to quit.
Use despite medical problems (e.g., COPD, cancer).

impact_on_life.school_work: Missed breaks, reduced productivity due to cravings or withdrawal.
impact_on_life.social: Smoking-related stigma, isolation from smoke-free environments.
impact_on_life.medical: Increased risk for cancer, cardiovascular disease, respiratory illness.

medications: Nicotine replacement therapy (patches, gum, lozenges, inhalers, nasal spray)
withdrawal_management: Gradual taper of nicotine replacement if used.
care_coordination: Primary care follow-up for smoking cessation.
Referral to quitlines or group cessation programs.

treatment_goals: Prevent relapse through coping skills and support.
Address comorbid psychiatric or medical conditions.
missed_diagnosis_factors: Clinician focus on other substance use while overlooking tobacco.
overdiagnosis_factors: Labeling occasional social smoking as a disorder without impairment or distress.
warning_signs: Need to smoke within minutes of waking.
self_help_strategies: Replace smoking with healthy oral habits (e.g., sugar-free gum).

adolescents: Initiation via vaping or peer smoking.
adults: Difficulty quitting due to stress or habit.
older_adults: Smoking to manage loneliness or boredom.

real_life_examples: A 16-year-old starts vaping with friends and develops daily nicotine cravings within weeks.
A middle-aged man smokes despite COPD diagnosis, citing stress as the reason.
An older adult smokes a pack a day for 40 years and struggles with withdrawal when hospitalized.
